title: 104_s2174
content:
In the approval of H-2A petitions, the Attorney General must consider the certification decision of the Secretary of Labor, any evidence provided by the employer regarding the unavailability of US workers, compliance with requirements, and may consult with the Secretary of Agriculture. Additionally, a condition for denial of labor certification is specified. Section 218(b)(4) of the Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to specify that the Secretary determines if the employer has filed a job offer with the appropriate local office of the State employment security agency. The job offer must meet certain criteria, including the required rate of pay. The employer must offer H-2A aliens and other workers in the area of intended employment a wage rate not less than the median rate for similar workers. They also need to provide housing to those who cannot return home the same day, meeting federal standards for temporary labor camps. The employer must offer H-2A aliens and other workers a wage rate not less than the median for similar workers and provide housing that meets federal standards for temporary labor camps or offer a housing allowance if housing is reasonably available in the area of employment. The Secretary shall promulgate special regulations allowing short-term temporary housing for workers in occupations lasting 40 days or less, and a transitional period for special housing standards in other employment for five years. The Secretary will approve housing meeting specific standards for occupations lasting over 40 days in areas with insufficient housing. State and local standards for temporary housing for agricultural workers will be preempted. Employers must reimburse transportation costs for H-2A aliens. The employer will reimburse H-2A aliens and workers from distant locations for transportation and subsistence costs if they complete 50% of the employment period. If the worker completes the full period, the employer will also provide transportation and subsistence to their next place of employment. The employer must guarantee three-fourths of the workdays for H-2A workers and prefer United States workers for employment. The employer must guarantee three-fourths of the workdays for H-2A workers and give preference to United States workers who are immediately available for job opportunities. SEC. 3. SPECIAL RULES FOR LABOR CERTIFICATIONS. Section 218(c) of the Immigration and Nationality Act is amended regarding the issuance of labor certifications by the Secretary. Special rules include a deadline for filing applications and notification of deficiencies within seven days. The Secretary shall notify the employer of any deficiencies in the application and allow for resubmission. Certification must be provided to the employer at least 20 days before labor or services are required, stating reasons for approval or denial. The Secretary provides employers with information on qualified workers for job offers approved by the Secretary, allowing employers to contact referred workers for reconfirmation. The Secretary allows employers to contact referred workers to reconfirm availability for work. If there are unfilled job opportunities in the same occupation and area, certification is provided when the job offer is approved. SEC. 4. EXPEDITED APPEALS OF CERTAIN DETERMINATIONS.

Amendment to Section 218(e) of the Immigration and Nationality Act for expedited appeals of nonapproval of job offers and denial of certification. 

SEC. 5. PROCEDURES FOR THE CONSIDERATION OF H-2A PETITIONS. Section 218 of the Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to include expedited processing procedures for H-2A petitions filed by employers. The Attorney General must adjudicate petitions within 15 days of filing and notify visa-issuing consulates and ports of entry. The Attorney General must provide an expedited procedure for amending H-2A petitions to increase the number of workers within five days before the employer's date of need. This is to replace workers whose availability cannot be confirmed, fail to report for work, abandon employment, or are terminated for cause. SEC. 6. LIMITATION ON EMPLOYER LIABILITY. Amends the Immigration and Nationality Act to limit employer liability based on employment actions conforming to approved job offers. No liability unless certification is amended or invalidated by the Secretary or a court order. SEC. 7. LIMITATION ON JUDICIAL REMEDIES. "Section 218(h) of the Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to limit court jurisdiction in issuing restraining orders or injunctions related to certification for H-2A workers."
